awd_titl_txt: RUI: Growth and Characterization of Epitaxial Zinc Oxide Films for Device Applications
awd_abstract_narration:
NON-TECHNICAL DESCRIPTION 
Zinc oxide (ZnO) is an attractive semiconductor material because of its unique characteristics such as better electronic and optical properties, greater radiation hardness, relative ease of its synthesis, and greater environmental friendliness. It is therefore useful for the fabrication of solar cells, light emitters (e.g., light emitting diodes(LEDs) and laser diodes), electronic devices for high power and high temperature applications, sensors and high-density data storage systems. Most of these applications require both n-type and p-type zinc oxide materials. While high quality n-type ZnO materials are readily available, it has proved difficult to develop p-type ZnO materials. This research will investigate the technique of delta-doping for the production of highly conductive p-type ZnO materials. This technique, which has proved successful with other semiconductor materials, involves confining p-type doping atoms in a narrow layer of the host ZnO material. With successful development of p-type ZnO materials, this project could make positive impact to the economic growth, energy savings, and environmental conservation efforts. This project will provide education and training of graduate and undergraduate students in semiconductor materials research using cutting-edge techniques that will prepare them for hi-tech careers or further graduate education, and will also be integrated with the Condensed Matter Physics course that attracts students from several science and engineering departments. Outreach to K-12 students as well as participation of YSU students from the underrepresented groups (women and minorities) will be pursued.

TECHNICAL DESCRIPTION
While ZnO shares several electronic and optical properties with GaN, it has a higher exciton binding energy, greater radiation hardness, is available in bulk and requires simpler crystal growth and processing technology. These advantages make it uniquely attractive for fabricating various electronic, optical and spintronic devices. However, the presence of high intrinsic n-type impurity concentration has hindered achievement of good quality p-type ZnO materials necessary for device fabrication. The objective of this project is to achieve high conductivity p-type ZnO films using delta doping by magnetron sputter deposition. Delta doping has successfully yielded enhanced p-type doping in many wide band gap semiconductors with similar p-type doping challenges. The p-type doping atoms will be spatially confined in a narrow layer, resulting in a two-dimensional doping density profile with a unique V-shaped potential well, which exceeds the solubility limit of the commonly used homogeneous doping. This project could lead to transformational outcomes as it will not only impact semiconductor device development, but also permit investigation of the basic science related to the fundamental limits of doping profile miniaturization.

Zinc oxide (ZnO) has been recognized as a material for fabricating photonic and electronic devices. Its utilization has been hampered by the difficulty to obtain good p-type (positive-type) materials. The objective of this RUI research project was to investigate “delta-doping” technique for the production of highly conductive p-type ZnO films. In this technique, dopant atoms are introduced within a narrow layer of the host material. This differes from traditional “uniform” doping where the doping atoms are spread all over the volume of the material.

 Within the context of intellectual merrit, the following outcomes were realized in this project:

 Undoped ZnO films: (i) We investigated undoped ZnO films deposited on sapphire substrates and found that films deposited at 300 °C using Ar:O2 (1:1) had the best optical and microstructure qualities. Pre-heating the sapphire substrate in oxygen prior to deposition was found to create a smoother sapphire surface. (ii) We found that a substrate temperature of 900 oC was needed for depositing undoped ZnO film with low defect density suitable for use as the buffer layer on the sapphire substrate. There is a large mismatch between the atomic lattice of ZnO and sapphire. For this reason, a buffer layer is required to reduce defects undesirable for p-type growth when sapphire is used. The films deposited at lower temperatures had higher density of defects called “stacking faults” as observed from the atomic resolution transmission electron microscope.

 p-type ZnO films: (i) We studied ZnO films doped with phosphorus (P) or arsenic (As) in the attempt to get p-type conductivity. Even with delta-doping, the samples were all n-type with high resistance. We used Hall effect measurement system equiped with ability to measure the film properties at high temperatures. We found there was a deep seated defect called “oxygen vacancy” in the doped ZnO thin films that prevented the attainment of p-type conductivity in the films. (ii) We investigated co-doping along with delta doping for obtaining p-type ZnO. In this method, we introduced two doping atoms, lithium (Li) and phosphorus simultaneously by sputtering from a ceramic target of lithium phosphate (Li3PO4). Traditional uniform doping was done by performing simultaneous uninterrupted deposition from the ZnO and Li3PO4 targets. For delta-doping, the deposition from the ZnO target was uninterrupted while that from the Li3PO4 was interrupted periodically using a shutter. Both methods produced films with good optical properties. The delta-doped samples had p-type doping concentration of 1.5 x 1016 cm-3 while the uniform doped samples had a concentration of 3.8 x 1013 cm-3. However, in some cases the conductivities fluctuated between positive and negative. Nevertheless, our results showed that delta-doping makes a very significant impact towards achieving p-type conductivity in ZnO. (iii) We similarly investigated the effect of delta-doping for improving the quality of n-type ZnO. Uniform doped n-type ZnO films were deposited from ZnO mixed with 2% aluminum, while the delta-doped n-type ZnO films were deposited from ZnO and Al targets. The delta-doped samples had a doping concentration that was ten times higher than that of the uniform doped samples, indicating the advantage of delta doping over uniform doping for n-type ZnO.
